May it please your good L. As my duty re
q
reth,
and as I
mised your L. when I shall have any matter
of mom
e
t to report, I will allwaies have a care to lett
you know it w
t
e soonest. We are in hand at
this p
nt
w
t
e towne of
Gertrudenbergh,
w
c
Count
Maurice
will endevour to take by surprise, having secret
intelligence w
t
some w
t
in
e towne, and good informa
o
n
of
e weakenesse of a Bulwarke, w
c
he purposeth
to scale. The attempt will be giv
e
w
t
in these two
daies, and in case it should faile, it is meant he shall
besiege it, and blocke up
e advenues, w
c
are but two
narrow passages, and as he is
suaded may be easely
defended against
e force of
e Enemie: and w
at
soever
shall befalle, they may make their retraite to
e towne
of
Breda.
There are w
t
in Gertrudenbergh but
600 souldiers, w
c
are, as we heare, in very great wantes
both for victuals and powder. It is thought
t
our
troupes will amo
u
t about
e number of 5000 foote,
and 1500 horse. Our l
re
s out of
Brabant
tell of divers disc
o
t
e
tem
ts
in
e Enemies gouvernm
t
partly against
e
owld
old count Mansfeld
, who
is hated for his rigour, and partialitie in dealing, and
partly am
o
g themselves, through their factions and wantes,
w
c
we are in good hope, will advance our designes.
Howbeit there is a bruite
t
Mons
r
Baligny
e Governo
r
of
Cambray,
who we were of beliefe, inclined more
and more to
e
F
r
Kinges
cause, hath heard suche newes
out of
Spaine,
as he hath paied his garrison, and
t
very
lately, w
t
Spanishe mony.
W
c
is all
t
I c
a
signifie,
but
t
I rest most addicted to doe your L. any service,
and so I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage.
